summary: An email from a U.S. Attorney to an attorney representing a victim/witness in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, discussing the commencement of discovery production under a new protective order. The email addresses procedures for protecting victim identities and notifying defense counsel of victim representation.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney
persons.context: Author of the email, informing victim's counsel about discovery procedures and the protective order in the Maxwell case.

events.title: Protective Order Entered in Maxwell Case
events.description: The court granted the government's motion for a protective order, ruling against defense arguments to publicly identify victims and imposing strict confidentiality on discovery materials.

events.title: Commencement of Discovery Production
events.description: The government plans to begin making initial discovery productions to Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team, including materials containing victim information.

keyFacts: A protective order was entered in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, strongly prohibiting the defense from publicly disclosing the identity of any victims or witnesses.
The government is beginning to produce discovery materials that include victim information such as names and dates of birth.
The government seeks permission from victim's counsel to identify them to the defense to preempt direct contact attempts with represented witnesses.
The document highlights the prosecution's efforts to balance transparency with protecting victim confidentiality during the discovery process.
